mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="f(s)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}a(n)\exp{-\lambda(n)s}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>exp</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $(RZ)_n$ is the $n$th entry of the column vector $RZ$.\\
Note that $f(s)=F(sB)$, so $F(Z)$ converges absolutely for $\re Z=\sigma_0B$ if and only if $f(s)$ converges absolutely for $\sigma=\sigma_0$.

We fix a sequence of exponents $\Lambda =\{\lambda(n)\}$ and a basis $B$ of $\Lambda$, so that we may write $\Lambda=R B$. Consider two general Dirichlet series with the same sequence of exponents $\Lambda$, say
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="F(Z)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}a(n)\exp{-(RZ)_{n}}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>Z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>exp</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>Z</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

Note that $f(s)=F(sB)$, so $F(Z)$ converges absolutely for $\re Z=\sigma_0B$ if and only if $f(s)$ converges absolutely for $\sigma=\sigma_0$.

We fix a sequence of exponents $\Lambda =\{\lambda(n)\}$ and a basis $B$ of $\Lambda$, so that we may write $\Lambda=R B$. Consider two general Dirichlet series with the same sequence of exponents $\Lambda$, say

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="f(s)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}a(n)\exp{-\lambda(n)s}\quad\hbox{and}\quad g(s)=\sum_{%
n=1}^{\infty}b(n)\exp{-\lambda(n)s}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>exp</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mtext>and</mtext></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>exp</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: Then, we say that $f(s)$ and $g(s)$ are \emph{equivalent} ($f\sim g$), with respect to $B$, if there exists a sequence of real numbers $Y=\{y(n)\}$ such that
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="b(n)=a(n)\exp{i(RY)_{n}}\quad\hbox{ for every }n." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>Y</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mrow><mtext> for every </mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: Moreover, if $S_f(\sigma_1,\sigma_2)$ is the set of values taken by $f(s)$ in the strip $\alpha\leq\sigma_1<\sigma<\sigma_2\leq \infty$, then
text: $$\conj{V_f(\sigma_0)}=\{g(\sigma_0)\mid g(s)\hbox{ is a general Dirichlet series equivalent to }f(s)\}.$$
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\conj{V_{f}(\sigma_{0})}=\{g(\sigma_{0})\mid g(s)\hbox{ is a general Dirichlet%
 series equivalent to }f(s)\}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\conj</mtext></merror><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>∣</mo><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> is a general Dirichlet series equivalent to </mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: Moreover, if $S_f(\sigma_1,\sigma_2)$ is the set of values taken by $f(s)$ in the strip $\alpha\leq\sigma_1<\sigma<\sigma_2\leq \infty$, then
text: $$S_f(\sigma_1,\sigma_2) = \{g(\sigma)\mid \sigma\in(\sigma_1,\sigma_2),\,g(s)\hbox{ is a general Dirichlet series equivalent to }f(s)\}.$$
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="S_{f}(\sigma_{1},\sigma_{2})=\{g(\sigma)\mid\sigma\in(\sigma_{1},\sigma_{2}),%
\,g(s)\hbox{ is a general Dirichlet series equivalent to }f(s)\}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>σ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>∣</mo><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> is a general Dirichlet series equivalent to </mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="f_{1}(s)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{n^{s}}\quad\hbox{and}\quad f_{2}(s)=\sum_%
{n=2}^{\infty}\frac{1}{n^{s}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mi>n</mi><mi>s</mi></msup></mfrac></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mtext>and</mtext></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mi>n</mi><mi>s</mi></msup></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
To prove that $f_1(s)$ and $f_2(s)$ are equivalent, we need to fix a basis $B=\{\beta(n)\}$ for $\Lambda=\{\lambda(n)\}$ and find $Y\subset\R$ such that \eqref{eq:equiv} holds. We take $B$ by removing linearly dependent elements from $\Lambda$ as follows. For the first element we take the first nonzero $\lambda(n)$ (which is either $\lambda(1)$ or $\lambda(2)$) and we call it $\beta(1)$. We choose $\beta(2)$ to be the first $\lambda(n)$ which is not a rational multiple of $\beta(1)$. We choose $\beta(3)$ to be the first $\lambda(n)$ which is not a rational linear combination of $\beta(1)$ and $\beta(2)$, and so on. It is easy to check that $B=\{\beta(1),\beta(2),\ldots\}=\{\lambda(n_1),\lambda(n_2),\ldots\}$ is a basis for $\Lambda$ by construction (cf. \cite[Theorem 8.4]{apostol}).

Having fixed a basis, then every $g_j(s)$ equivalent to $f_j(s)$ is determined by a sequence $Y_{g_{j}}\subset\R$, $j=1,2$ (see \eqref{eq:equiv}). In particular, for any $\delta\geq0$ and any $g_j(s)$ equivalent to $f_j(s)$ we have
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="S_{f_{j}}(\sigma_{0},\infty)=\{g_{j}(\sigma)\mid\sigma>\sigma_{0},\,g_{j}\sim f%
_{j}\},\quad j=1,2." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>S</mi><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>σ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>∣</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>></mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt">,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>∼</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="12.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $r_1$ is such that $\lambda(1)=r_1\beta(1)$. Then, we consider the set

To prove that $f_1(s)$ and $f_2(s)$ are equivalent, we need to fix a basis $B=\{\beta(n)\}$ for $\Lambda=\{\lambda(n)\}$ and find $Y\subset\R$ such that \eqref{eq:equiv} holds. We take $B$ by removing linearly dependent elements from $\Lambda$ as follows. For the first element we take the first nonzero $\lambda(n)$ (which is either $\lambda(1)$ or $\lambda(2)$) and we call it $\beta(1)$. We choose $\beta(2)$ to be the first $\lambda(n)$ which is not a rational multiple of $\beta(1)$. We choose $\beta(3)$ to be the first $\lambda(n)$ which is not a rational linear combination of $\beta(1)$ and $\beta(2)$, and so on. It is easy to check that $B=\{\beta(1),\beta(2),\ldots\}=\{\lambda(n_1),\lambda(n_2),\ldots\}$ is a basis for $\Lambda$ by construction (cf. \cite[Theorem 8.4]{apostol}).

Having fixed a basis, then every $g_j(s)$ equivalent to $f_j(s)$ is determined by a sequence $Y_{g_{j}}\subset\R$, $j=1,2$ (see \eqref{eq:equiv}). In particular, for any $\delta\geq0$ and any $g_j(s)$ equivalent to $f_j(s)$ we have

nexttext:
This immediately implies that $|a_2(1)|=|a_1(1)|$, and that in particular $a_2(1)=a_1(1)\exp{ir_1y(1)}$ for some $y(1)\in\R$.\\
If $r_1=1$, then $y(1)$ is uniquely determined mod $2\pi$ so we take $Y=\{y(1),0,\ldots\}$; otherwise we have $\lambda(1)=r_1=0$ and $\beta(1)=\lambda(2)$, and we may take $Y=\{0,0,\ldots\}$.

This immediately implies that $|a_2(1)|=|a_1(1)|$, and that in particular $a_2(1)=a_1(1)\exp{ir_1y(1)}$ for some $y(1)\in\R$.\\
If $r_1=1$, then $y(1)$ is uniquely determined mod $2\pi$ so we take $Y=\{y(1),0,\ldots\}$; otherwise we have $\lambda(1)=r_1=0$ and $\beta(1)=\lambda(2)$, and we may take $Y=\{0,0,\ldots\}$. 

We now work by induction on $n$. Suppose that there exists a sequence $Y=\{y(n)\}$ such that
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex13.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="a_{2}(k)=a_{1}(k)\exp{i(RY)_{k}}\quad\hbox{for every }k\leq n," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>Y</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>k</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mrow><mrow><mtext>for every </mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: We write $f_1^Y(s)=\sum a_1(n)\exp{i(RY)_n}\exp{-\lambda(n)s}$, and we consider $f_1^{(n)}(s)=f_1^Y(s)-\sum_{k\leq n} a_2(k)\exp{-\lambda(k)s}$ and $f_2^{(n)}(s)=f_2(s)-\sum_{k\leq n} a_2(k)\exp{-\lambda(k)s}$. Since by Theorem \ref{theorem:bohr_equivalence} we have $S_{f_1}(\sigma_0,\infty)=S_{f_1^Y}(\sigma_0,\infty)$ for every $\sigma_0>\alpha$, from $f_1^{(n)}(s)-f_1^Y(s)=f_2^{(n)}(s)-f_2(s)$ and by hypothesis we obtain $S_{f_1^{(n)}}(\sigma_0,\infty)=S_{f_2^{(n)}}(\sigma_0,\infty)$ for every $\sigma_0>\alpha$. Therefore, we also get
prevtext: which is true for $n=1$. Then we want to show that there exists a sequence $Y'=\{y'(n)\}$ such that

nexttext: If $\lambda(n+1)\not\in B$, then we necessarily have that either $\exp{i(RY_g)_{n+1}}=1$ or $a_1(n+1)=0$; in both cases we may take $Y'=Y$. Indeed, if we consider $f_1^{(n+1)}(s)=f_1^Y(s)-\sum_{k\leq n+1} a_2(k)\exp{-\lambda(k)s}$ and $f_2^{(n)}(s)=f_2(s)-\sum_{k\leq n+1} a_2(k)\exp{-\lambda(k)s}$, then, reasoning as before, we obtain
prevtext: Analogously as in the case $n=1$, from \eqref{eq:T_f_n} we deduce that $|a_2(n+1)|=|a_1(n+1)|$, and that in particular $a_2(n+1)=a_1(n+1)\exp{i(RY)_{n+1}}\exp{i(RY_g)_{n+1}}$ for some $g\sim f_1^{(n)}$. If $\lambda(n+1)=\beta(m)\in B$ for some $m$, then we take $Y'$ so that
text:
$$y'(n)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
y(n)& n< m,\\
y(n)+y_g(n) & n\geq m.
\end{array}\right.$$
